commit_message:
Make scheduler_driver option can be clean up

Current, scheduler_driver option can't be cleaned up even we set it
to false. This patch just add ELSE logic to fix it.

Closes-Bug: #1435660
Change-Id: I7d4634f2e99a025cfde317fc2eb1240a81824803

commit_message:
Fixing defcore test list generation

Currently a test list must include the test tags as part of the test
name. This patch will filter the list of discovered tests against the
defcore list, to produce a test list with the proper test names
(including tags).

Change-Id: Ifdbd6ff9140f8fd7da332dde33de507d86e2015d
Closes-Bug: #1426442
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/29/167329/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: string=$(python <<ENDEND) read -a test_list <<<$string parse_cmd="grep " for item in ${test_list[@]}; do parse_cmd+="-e $item "; done $parse_cmd

subject: Remove use of contextlib.nested
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-05 09:34:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/74c10072036d3fafad7df5b30430af986811321c', 'message': 'Remove use of contextlib.nested

The contextlib.nested call has been deprecated
in Python 2.7. This causes DeprecationWarning
messages in the unit tests.

There are also known issues with contextlib.nested
that were addressed by the native support for
multiple "with" variables. For instance, if the
first object is created but the second one throws
an exception, the first object's __exit__ is never
called. For more information see
https://docs.python.org/2/library/contextlib.html#contextlib.nested
contextlib.nested is also not compatible in Python 3.

Since Glance no longer supports 2.6 we can remove
the use of these contextlib.nested calls.

Added hacking check to catch if any new instances
are added to the codebase.

commit_message:
Remove use of contextlib.nested

The contextlib.nested call has been deprecated
in Python 2.7. This causes DeprecationWarning
messages in the unit tests.

There are also known issues with contextlib.nested
that were addressed by the native support for
multiple "with" variables. For instance, if the
first object is created but the second one throws
an exception, the first object's __exit__ is never
called. For more information see
https://docs.python.org/2/library/contextlib.html#contextlib.nested
contextlib.nested is also not compatible in Python 3.

Since Glance no longer supports 2.6 we can remove
the use of these contextlib.nested calls.

Added hacking check to catch if any new instances
are added to the codebase.

Closes-Bug: #1428424
Change-Id: Ic8edfa41d6c468cf6db8d11d3533e4f8cf2053c2

subject: Allow node.instance_uuid to be removed during cleaning
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-23 22:58:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/20d67a7d06c77c497c21f95f4907c8f025e7ae94', 'message': "Allow instance_uuid to be removed during cleaning

As soon as Nova moves the node's provision state to DELETING, it
attempts to remove the instance UUID. Ironic throws an error because
it considers the node in a state transition. If cleaning takes longer
than the Nova timeout, the delete will error out.

The fix is to allow node updates while the node is in CLEANING state.
In L, we should fix the Nova driver to not remove the instance
UUID, and clear it after tear down when we clear out node.instance_info.

Also allows updates to nodes in CLEANFAIL to match the other states
in UPDATE_ALLOWED_STATES.

Change-Id: I46771041f90a1d52f6b2d8e107ca10b650b720c1
Closes-Bug: 1435605
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-24 18:39:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/910a97c0a406d2f63ea1b3f902f0c383846ef3d8', 'message': "Allow instance_uuid to be removed during cleaning

As soon as Nova moves the node's provision state to DELETING, it
attempts to remove the instance UUID. Ironic throws an error because
it considers the node in a state transition. If cleaning takes longer
than the Nova timeout, the delete will error out.

The fix is to allow instance uuid removal  while the node is in CLEANING
state. In L, we should fix the Nova driver to not remove the instance
UUID, and clear it after tear down when we clear out node.instance_info.

Also allows updates to nodes in CLEANFAIL to match the other states
in UPDATE_ALLOWED_STATES, and if the node fails CLEANING quickly, the
instance UUID removal could happen here.

Change-Id: I46771041f90a1d52f6b2d8e107ca10b650b720c1
Closes-Bug: 1435605

commit_message:
Allow node.instance_uuid to be removed during cleaning

As soon as Nova moves the node's provision state to DELETING, it
attempts to remove the node's instance UUID. Ironic throws an error
because it considers the node in a state transition. If cleaning
takes longer than the Nova timeout, the delete will error out.

The fix is to allow node.instance_uuid removal while the node is in
CLEANING state. In L, we should fix the Nova driver to not remove
node.instance_uuid, and clear it after tear down when we clear out
node.instance_info.

Also allows updates to nodes in CLEANFAIL to match the other states
in UPDATE_ALLOWED_STATES, and if the node fails CLEANING quickly, the
node.instance_uuid removal could happen here.

Change-Id: I46771041f90a1d52f6b2d8e107ca10b650b720c1
Closes-Bug: 1435605
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/33/167033/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: UPDATE_ALLOWED_STATES = (DEPLOYFAIL, INSPECTING, INSPECTFAIL, CLEANFAIL, CLEANING) """Transitional states in which we allow updating a node. TODO(JoshNang) remove CLEANING in L, remove instance uuid when cleaning instance_info, stop removing instance_uuid in the Nova Ironic driver. """
deleted_lines: UPDATE_ALLOWED_STATES = (DEPLOYFAIL, INSPECTING, INSPECTFAIL) """Transitional states in which we allow updating a node."""

commit_message:
run_tests.sh: removed bash dependency

It is not always a good idea to guess that
everyone uses bash. There are other
even more functional shells. So, if it is possible
to avoid specific shell dependency we certainly
need to do this.

Closes-bug: 1430517
Change-Id: Iff529c63f333b382a3a6d6304d42ee3259c33cae

commit_message:
Always defines tempest_roles as Member

Because tests might force the auth version to v3, we always need
to have Member in the list of roles.

Backported from: 72f026b60d350ede39e22e08b8f7f286fd0d2633

Change-Id: I06fd043e1b31ae0e5e33f4dcf898fb58f2907267

commit_message:
Update rabbitmq_package_url

Changed the rabbitmq package url to point to the pinned version of rabbitmq
as found within the https://mirror.rackspace.com/rackspaceprivatecloud repo.
This change is a stabilization change that will ensure that we have a
mirrored copy of the version of rabbitmq that we believe is production ready.

Change-Id: I55b28f073a3ed3e0924cdd0007149bb1d9de21f7
(cherry picked from commit a7d245ec4d917cb2659157df8c56edddaf911d43)
Closes-Bug: #1436240

commit_message:
support the ldap user_enabled_invert parameter

The ldap backend has a new parameter called user_enabled_invert.
This should be supported by puppet.

Closes-Bug: #1383779
Change-Id: I6d10408b15fa56610e25b37d3962067e8361da5c
(cherry picked from commit 99fd7bf3cbe4c18dbda70eb8c689cb7d7e2de57f)

added_lines: $user_enabled_invert = undef, 'ldap/user_enabled_invert': value => $user_enabled_invert;

commit_message:
OVS_LIB API addition - change bridge controller connection-mode

Add an API to change controller connection mode to 'out-of-band', feature
which might be useful for many projects using Openflow controller with OVS

Change-Id: I8b07079d33384684060b56cfd29274c9716a0a78
Closes-Bug: #1433208

commit_message:
Add option to delete ports after introspection

Tuned by 'keep_ports' option:
* all (the default) - do nothing
* present - delete ports not in introspection data
* added - delete all ports except for what was created by introspection

Change-Id: I54741e3101759f0bbf40d6fa99c66b5f6ec211f3
Closes-Bug: #1404279
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector refs/changes/15/166915/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ; Which ports already present on a node to keep after introspection. Values: ; all (do not delete anything), present (keep ports which MACs were present ; in introspection data), added (keep only MACs that we added). ;keep_ports = all

commit_message:
Update documentation for glance-manage

Currently the documentation of glance-manage is missing the commands
to handle the glance metadata defnition. This patch provides details
on following commands:

db_load_metadefs
db_unload_metadefs
db_export_metadefs

Closes-Bug: #1414725

Change-Id: I90865831d38478f76e7379ca447ed99c17387710
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/97/166597/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: **db_export_metadefs** Export the meta definitions into json format. By default the definitions are exported to /etc/glance/metadefs directory. **db_load_metadefs** Load the meta definitions into glance database. By default the definitions are imported from /etc/glance/metadefs directory. **db_unload_metadefs** Unload the meta definitions. Clears the contents of all the glance db tables including metadef_namespace_resource_types, metadef_tags, metadef_objects, metadef_resource_types, metadef_namespaces and metadef_properties.

commit_message:
Switch to TLSv1 as SSLv3 is considered insecure and is disabled by default

Rabbitmq won't talk to us anymore if we try to use SSLv3 as it disabled
support for SSLv3. Openstack components use python's openssl
implementation which does not support TLSv1.1 and TLSv1.2 yet so we
just switch to TLSv1. Support for newer TLS should come with python
2.7.9+

Closes-Bug: #1409667
Change-Id: I949421cd092a31eab3ef7f2194c4da3a9dbac818
(cherry picked from commit c231da8de6d3ef14a23259d1d8e05c7b6c6d83ba)

commit_message:
Remove hyphen from rand_name calls in baremetal tests

data_utils.rand_name() appends randam charactors with a hypen like:

 def rand_name(name=''):
     randbits = str(random.randint(1, 0x7fffffff))
     if name:
         return name + '-' + randbits

So it is not necessary to specify a hypen in caller side.
This patch removes a hypen in baremetal tests.

Change-Id: I43fde9b537f7d225266ebb3950b6768aa7ae9fae

commit_message:
Pass identity_version into get_credentials

When identity_version is passed into get_configured_credentials,
pass that into the call to get_credentials as well.

Change-Id: Icfe1efa131518f3190b53b781bfb9b35176eea5d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/88/167788/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from tempest_lib import auth credentials = get_credentials(fill_in=fill_in, identity_version=identity_version, **params) class TestCredentials(auth.Credentials): """Mimics Credentials, with network details added It behaves like credentials from a consumer point of view, only it provides a new dict attribute 'network': {'id': network_id, 'name': network_name} To setup TestCredentials, a 'network_provider' is required, which is a parameter-less callable, which returns the network dict. """ def __init__(self, network_provider, **kwargs): super(TestCredentials, self).__init__(**kwargs) self.network_provider = network_provider self._network = None @property def network(self): if not self._network: self._network = self.network_provider()

commit_message:
Remove hyphen from rand_name calls in image tests

data_utils.rand_name() appends randam charactors with a hypen like:

 def rand_name(name=''):
     randbits = str(random.randint(1, 0x7fffffff))
     if name:
         return name + '-' + randbits

So it is not necessary to specify a hypen in caller side.
This patch removes a hypen in image tests

Change-Id: Iac422b107ca558e5b41d9ad3fbde051b012df56c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/67/166667/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: tag = data_utils.rand_name('tag') tag = data_utils.rand_name('non-exist-tag')

subject: Implement clustering for Vertica datastore
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-26 18:29:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/fb644c0341b4536466aa600cd3306ca27e45e1ff', 'message': 'Implement clustering for Vertica datastore

- HP Vertica Community Edition supports upto a 3-node cluster.
- For the purpose of fault tolerance, it needs to have a minimum of
  3-nodes in instance, so that if one of them goes down, still
  cluster can sustain.
- This patchset provides ability to launch HP Vertica 3-node cluster.
- The cluster-show API, would also list the IPs of underlying instances.

Code Added:
- Added new API strategy, taskmanager strategy, and guestagent strategy.
- Included unit tests for the new code.

Workflow for building Vertica cluster is as follows:
- Guest instances are booted using new API strategy which then
  sends control to taskmanager strategy for further communication
  and guestagent API execution.
- Once the guest instances are active in nova,
  they receives "prepare" message and following steps are performed:
    - Mount the data disk on device_path.
    - Check if vertica packages have been installed, install_if_needed().
    - Run Vertica pre-install test, prepare_for_install_vertica().
    - Gets to a status BUILD_PENDING
- Cluster-Taskmanager strategy waits for all the instances
  in cluster to get to BUILD_PENDING state.
- Once all instances in a cluster get to BUILD_PENDING state,
  taskmanager first, configures passwordless ssh for os-users(root, dbadmin)
  with the help of guestagent APIs get_keys and authroize_keys.
- Once passwordless ssh has been configured, the taskmanager calls install_cluster
  guestagent API, which installs cluster on member instances and
  creates a database on the cluster.
- Once this method finishes its job then taskmanager calls another guestagent API
  to notify cluster member of completion of cluster creation.

New Files:
- A new directory, vertica, has been created, for api, taskmanager,
  guestagent strategies under
  trove/common/strategies/cluster, basically the cluster-strategies.
- Files containing unit-tests for cluster-controller, api, and taskmanager code.

Change-Id: Ide30d1d2a136c7e638532a115db5ff5ab2a75e72
Implements: blueprint implement-vertica-cluster

    - Run Vertica pre-install test, prepare_for_install_vertica().
    - Gets to a status BUILD_PENDING
- Cluster-Taskmanager strategy waits for all the instances

- Unit-tests for cluster-controller, api and taskmanager code.

Change-Id: Ide30d1d2a136c7e638532a115db5ff5ab2a75e72

  notify cluster member of completion of cluster creation.

New Files:
- A new directory, vertica, has been created, for api, taskmanager,
  guestagent strategies under
  trove/common/strategies/cluster/experimental.
- Unit-tests for cluster-controller, api and taskmanager code.

Change-Id: Ide30d1d2a136c7e638532a115db5ff5ab2a75e72

'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-03-18 18:22:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/6480a704151ad0712214a1df1a594ddc4465f554', 'message': 'Implement clustering for Vertica datastore

A specification for this change was submitted for review in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/151279/

- HP Vertica Community Edition supports upto a 3-node cluster.
- HP Vertica requires a minimum of 3 nodes to achieve fault tolerance.
- This patchset provides ability to launch HP Vertica 3-node cluster.
- The cluster-show API, would also list the IPs of underlying instances.

Code Added:
- Added new API strategy, taskmanager strategy, and guestagent strategy.
- Included unit tests.

Workflow for building Vertica cluster is as follows:
- Guest instances are booted using new API strategy which then
  sends control to taskmanager strategy for further communication
  and guestagent API execution.
- Once the guest instances are active in nova,
  they receives "prepare" message and following steps are performed:
    - Mount the data disk on device_path.
    - Check if vertica packages have been installed, install_if_needed().
    - Run Vertica pre-install test, prepare_for_install_vertica().
    - Gets to a status BUILD_PENDING
- Cluster-Taskmanager strategy waits for all the instances
  in cluster to get to BUILD_PENDING state.
- Once all instances in a cluster get to BUILD_PENDING state,
  taskmanager first, configures passwordless ssh for os-users(root, dbadmin)
  with the help of guestagent APIs get_keys and authroize_keys.
- Once passwordless ssh has been configured, the taskmanager calls
  install_cluster guestagent API, which installs cluster on
  member instances and creates a database on the cluster.
- Once this method finishes its job then taskmanager calls
  another guestagent API cluster_complete to
  notify cluster member of completion of cluster creation.

New Files:
- A new directory, vertica, has been created, for api, taskmanager,
  guestagent strategies under
  trove/common/strategies/cluster/experimental.
- Unit-tests for cluster-controller, api and taskmanager code.

Change-Id: Ide30d1d2a136c7e638532a115db5ff5ab2a75e72
Implements: blueprint implement-vertica-cluster

commit_message:
Implement clustering for Vertica datastore

A specification for this change was submitted for review in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/151279

- HP Vertica Community Edition supports upto a 3-node cluster.
- HP Vertica requires a minimum of 3 nodes to achieve fault tolerance.
- This patchset provides ability to launch HP Vertica 3-node cluster.
- The cluster-show API, would also list the IPs of underlying instances.

Code Added:
- Added API strategy, taskmanager strategy, and guestagent strategy.
- Included unit tests.

Workflow for building Vertica cluster is as follows:
- Guest instances are booted using new API strategy which then
  sends control to taskmanager strategy for further communication
  and guestagent API execution.
- Once the guest instances are active in nova,
  they receive "prepare" message and following steps are performed:
    - Mount the data disk on device_path.
    - Check if vertica packages have been installed, install_if_needed().
    - Run Vertica pre-install test, prepare_for_install_vertica().
    - Get to a status BUILD_PENDING.
- Cluster-Taskmanager strategy waits for all the instances
  in cluster to get to BUILD_PENDING state.
- Once all instances in a cluster get to BUILD_PENDING state,
  taskmanager first, configures passwordless ssh for os-users(root, dbadmin)
  with the help of guestagent APIs get_keys and authroize_keys.
- Once passwordless ssh has been configured, the taskmanager calls
  install_cluster guestagent API, which installs cluster on
  member instances and creates a database on the cluster.
- Once this method finishes its job then taskmanager calls
  another guestagent API cluster_complete to
  notify cluster member of completion of cluster creation.

New Files:
- A new directory, vertica, has been created, for api, taskmanager,
  guestagent strategies under
  trove/common/strategies/cluster/experimental.
- Unit-tests for cluster-controller, api and taskmanager code.

DocImpact
Change-Id: Ide30d1d2a136c7e638532a115db5ff5ab2a75e72
Implements: blueprint implement-vertica-cluster
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/66/159566/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if cluster_config is None: self.app.install_vertica() self.app.create_db() self.app.complete_install_or_restart() elif cluster_config['instance_type'] == "member": self.appStatus.set_status(rd_ins.ServiceStatuses.BUILD_PENDING) else: LOG.error(_("Bad cluster configuration; instance type " "given as %s.") % cluster_config['instance_type']) raise def get_keys(self, context, user): LOG.debug("get_keys called.") return self.app.get_keys(user) def authorize_keys(self, context, user, keys): LOG.debug("authorized_keys called.") return self.app.authorize_keys(user, keys) def install_cluster(self, context, members): try: LOG.debug("install_cluster called.") LOG.debug("args: members=%s." % members) self.app.install_cluster(members) LOG.debug("install_cluster call has finished.") except Exception: self.appStatus.set_status(rd_ins.ServiceStatuses.FAILED) raise def cluster_complete(self, context): LOG.debug("Cluster creation complete, starting status checks.") status = self.appStatus._get_actual_db_status() self.appStatus.set_status(status)

subject: Update rabbitmq_package_url
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-25 16:31:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/a7d245ec4d917cb2659157df8c56edddaf911d43', 'message': "Update rabbitmq_package_url

This change removes the temporary rabbitmq_package_url override set in
gate-check-commit.sh and adds a group_vars entry so that o-a-d
installations will download rabbitmq-server from mirror.rackspace.com.
The role's default will remain pointed at the upstream rabbitmq.com
mirror.

commit_message:
Update rabbitmq_package_url

This change removes the temporary rabbitmq_package_url override set in
gate-check-commit.sh and adds a group_vars entry so that o-a-d
installations will download rabbitmq-server from mirror.rackspace.com.
The role's default will remain pointed at the upstream rabbitmq.com
mirror.

Change-Id: I55b28f073a3ed3e0924cdd0007149bb1d9de21f7
Closes-Bug: #1436240
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/81/167681/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rabbitmq_package_url: "http://mirror.rackspace.com/rackspaceprivatecloud/downloads/rabbitmq-server_3.4.3-1_all.deb"

commit_message:
Remove impossible records in downgrade migration

After filling cluster_changes table with data and
then downgrade it some values can become impossible
due to changes in Enum list and cause errors

Change-Id: I425a93298ad9aa0c5d4796e881da49dc7cce8420
Closes-Bug: #1434466

commit_message:
Fix in vmware serialization for multi-role node

  * fix in deployment serialization for multi-role node
  * fix dc and ds for glance
  * deny access to default vmware attributes when cluster
    doesn't support vmware configuration

Closes-Bug: #1431333
Change-Id: Ieabdd1b2c74c66dbea72e1bb4a97921a312e009e

commit_message:
Add lbaas package for Kilo in Red Hat platforms

Starting in Kilo, Red Hat platforms will also include LBaaS as a
separate package, see:

- http://trunk.rdoproject.org/f21/current/
- http://trunk.rdoproject.org/centos70/current/

Adjusting the lbaas manifest accordingly.

Change-Id: Ibd5d71a0e0e33a846a6a04aaf8f9f907f70526d4

commit_message:
Add support for passing api version to glance module

Glance API version 1 is deprecated as of kilo.  If we want to support
v2 moving forward, we should add support for passing a version in to
the glance module.  This commit does that, defaulting to 1 to keep
compatibility with current code in master.

Closes-Bug: 1435808
Change-Id: Ie6d1e10ad167d2e1e726c7532178992d2a8c51b7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/88/167188/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - false (private) api_version: description: - which version of the glance api to use choices: - 1 (default) - 2 p = self.module.params version=p['api_version'], api_version=dict(default='1', required=False, choices=['1', '2'])

commit_message:
Support actions with TableWidget

* Action tab was removed
* Now list of actions is available for each app via dropdown menu
* Modal spinner is shown on each action run. It has close sign,
  so user can stop waiting for action result at any moment.
  If action failed - exception details will be downloaded,
  if succeed - json with result or result file will be downloaded.

Implements blueprint support-action-result
Change-Id: I03596ee09847911ce087d819f3a1c050a84ed850

commit_message:
Fix Compute API labels

The commit Ibe990ec93d8f9d18ef21c28979e180472df6a33d changes Compute
API statuses based on the latest development status.
However, it didn't cover all parts in api-site doc.
This patch fixes the lack.

Change-Id: Id4f8d0cfcda46f48384a729bbeaa5823fbecc7ba
Related-Bug: #1435507

subject: Fix a usage error of joinedload + filter in l3 scheduler
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-23 02:14:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/6023b240b04618dfac532f8fae296d9920b893b6', 'message': "Fix some usage of joinedload + filter

With the current coding, joinedload() produces a JOIN and
the following filter() on the columns from the joined table
would create another JOIN of the same table.  It doesn't seem
to be the intended behaviour.  As a consequence the filter
doesn't work as expected.

Reference: http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_9/orm/loading_relationships.html#contains-eager

Change-Id: I2243cdfda5c6fe5ef67f96e3274d5381a6e50e62
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-01-27 06:13:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/ba796715872047663c326e50e9e0e51aecb875fa', 'message': "Fix some usage of joinedload + filter

With the current coding, joinedload() produces a JOIN and
the following filter() on the columns from the joined table
would create another JOIN of the same table.  It doesn't seem
to be the intended behaviour.  As a consequence the filter
doesn't work as expected.

Reference: http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_9/orm/loading_relationships.html#contains-eager

Change-Id: I2243cdfda5c6fe5ef67f96e3274d5381a6e50e62
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-01-27 06:46:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/35fec2508ef4a2237d7e22e125f2c0343e5b2937', 'message': "Fix a usage error of joinedload + filter in l3 scheduler

With the current coding, joinedload() produces a JOIN and
the following filter() on the columns from the joined table
would create another JOIN of the same table.  It doesn't seem
to be the intended behaviour.  As a consequence the filter
doesn't work as expected.

Also, adapt callers which rely on the current broken
implementation.

Reference: http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_9/orm/loading_relationships.html#contains-eager

Partial-Bug: #1414905
Closes-Bug: #1410841
Change-Id: I2243cdfda5c6fe5ef67f96e3274d5381a6e50e62
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-01-28 02:58:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/a235a3faac60df3c5b3cc49931b751ccd0a5ccf6', 'message': "Fix a usage error of joinedload + filter in l3 scheduler

This commit fixes admin_state_up filtering in
get_l3_agents_hosting_routers.  Also, adapt its callers
which rely on the current broken implementation.

Details:

With the current coding, joinedload() produces a JOIN and
the following filter() on the columns from the joined table
would create another JOIN of the same table.  (As t1 in the
following example).  It doesn't seem to be the intended
behaviour.  As a consequence the filter (WHERE clause in
the following examples) doesn't work as expected.

Queries before this fix looked like the following,
where t1 and t2 are Agent and RouterL3AgentBinding respectively:

    SELECT t2.aaa, t1_1.bbb, ...
    FROM t1, t2 LEFT OUTER JOIN t1 AS t1_1 ON t1_1.ccc = t2.ddd
    WHERE t1.eee = ...;

After the fix, it would be:

    SELECT t2.aaa, t1.bbb, ...
    FROM t2 JOIN t1 ON t1.ccc = t2.ddd
    WHERE t1.eee = ...;

Reference: http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_9/orm/loading_relationships.html#contains-eager

Partial-Bug: #1414905
Closes-Bug: #1410841
Change-Id: I2243cdfda5c6fe5ef67f96e3274d5381a6e50e62
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-01-30 05:33:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/12b8fc2159654c5fda94fca6b3ccdd35dc52dfe1', 'message': "Fix a usage error of joinedload + filter in l3 scheduler

This commit fixes admin_state_up filtering in
get_l3_agents_hosting_routers.  Also, adapt its callers
which rely on the current broken implementation.

Details:

With the current coding, joinedload() produces a JOIN and
the following filter() on the columns from the joined table
would create another JOIN of the same table.  (As t1 in the
following example).  It doesn't seem to be the intended
behaviour.  As a consequence the filter (WHERE clause in
the following examples) doesn't work as expected.

Queries before this fix looked like the following,
where t1 and t2 are Agent and RouterL3AgentBinding respectively:

    SELECT t2.aaa, t1_1.bbb, ...
    FROM t1, t2 LEFT OUTER JOIN t1 AS t1_1 ON t1_1.ccc = t2.ddd
    WHERE t1.eee = ...;

After the fix, it would be:

    SELECT t2.aaa, t1.bbb, ...
    FROM t2 JOIN t1 ON t1.ccc = t2.ddd

commit_message:
Fix a usage error of joinedload + filter in l3 scheduler

This commit fixes admin_state_up filtering in
get_l3_agents_hosting_routers.  Also, adapt its callers
which rely on the current broken implementation.

Details:

With the current coding, joinedload() produces a JOIN and
the following filter() on the columns from the joined table
would create another JOIN of the same table.  (As t1 in the
following example).  It doesn't seem to be the intended
behaviour.  As a consequence the filter (WHERE clause in
the following examples) doesn't work as expected.

Queries before this fix looked like the following,
where t1 and t2 are Agent and RouterL3AgentBinding respectively:

    SELECT t2.aaa, t1_1.bbb, ...
    FROM t1, t2 LEFT OUTER JOIN t1 AS t1_1 ON t1_1.ccc = t2.ddd
    WHERE t1.eee = ...;

After the fix, it would be:

    SELECT t2.aaa, t1.bbb, ...
    FROM t2 JOIN t1 ON t1.ccc = t2.ddd
    WHERE t1.eee = ...;

Reference: http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_9/orm/loading_relationships.html#contains-eager

Partial-Bug: #1414905
Closes-Bug: #1410841
Change-Id: I2243cdfda5c6fe5ef67f96e3274d5381a6e50e62

commit_message:
Using default network by multitenant drivers

Add functionality of using default shared network if no one was configured
in share creating request. Add default values for network name and subnet name
to configuration file.
Default share netwok creating in special "service" tenant where instances
for shares are creating. Default share network can be creted by admin manually
(in this case it should have "default" name) or automatically (in this case
parameters default_network_name and default_subnet_name will be used).

Change-Id: I624f3a4ffff1ca77cc4fb2bee068ee7956fedbf5
BP: default-network-for-multitenant-drivers

added_lines: def get_network_by_name(self, network_name): """Get specific network for client by its name""" try: networks = self.client.list_networks().get('networks', []) for network in networks: if network["name"] == network_name: return network return None except neutron_client_exc.NeutronClientException as e: raise exception.NetworkException(code=e.status_code, message=e.message) def get_subnet_by_name(self, subnet_name): """Get specific subnet for client by its name""" try: subnets = self.client.list_subnets().get('subnets', []) for subnet in subnets: if subnet["name"] == subnet_name: return subnet return None except neutron_client_exc.NeutronClientException as e: raise exception.NetworkException(code=e.status_code, message=e.message)

commit_message:
mirror/ubuntu: improve broken mirror/packages handling

If there are too many conflicting/broken packages mirroring script tries
to process the packages one by one. There were a couple of bugs lurking
in that code (wrong path to requirements-deb.txt, etc). While at it add
a warning regarding to many conflicting/broken packages.

Change-Id: I607897346313952db775bcaa1e49b11f248d3184
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/84/162884/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo 'repo.mk: WARNING: too many conflicting packages. Broken packages/mirror?' >&2; \ cat $(workdir)/apt_*.out $(workdir)/apt_*.log >&2; \ ( echo 'sources.list:'; cat '$(apt_altstate)/etc/apt/sources.list' ) >&2; \ echo 'Trying to process packages one by one (this is slow)' >&2; \ cp "$(workdir)/requirements-deb.txt" "$(conflicting_pkgs_list)" && \

commit_message:
Split page /project/volumes

Till now there are was "Volumes" and "Snapshots" on page /project/volumes. Now
this tabs have been converted to separate pages. Tab "Volumes" stays on page
/project/volumes, tab "Snapshots" moved to new page /project/snapshots.

Change-Id: Ice98c6d6023e4d9e3693ca26dfdc21efc096422a

commit_message:
Tweak API Quick Start curl commands and remove v3 in response

We dont publish the v3 endpoint anymore in response to /v2.0/tokens so
remove that from get_credentials_resp.json. Also fixup the curl
commands a bit to they would generate the output (formatted json).

commit_message:
Force to install test deps on the gate

This should fix the issue, that django-nose is
not being installed on the gate, when Django becomes
updated from Django-1.6.x to later versions.

Change-Id: Ic3e42fbce563aed2e61fb808d0482f8f7e19ce09
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/15/167515/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: export DEVSTACK_GATE_INSTALL_TESTONLY=1

added_lines: "POT-Creation-Date: 2015-03-26 05:50+0000\n" "PO-Revision-Date: 2015-03-26 05:51+0000\n"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2375(title) #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2545(title) #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2713(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml166(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml130(para) msgid "" "If possible, we highly recommended that you dump your production database " "tables and test the upgrade in your development environment using this data." ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2845(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2847(para)"Upgrades involve complex operations and can fail. Before attempting any " "upgrade, you should make a full database backup of your production data. As " "of Kilo, database downgrades are not supported, and the only method " "available to get back to a prior database version will be to restore from " "backup." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2853(para) msgid "" "This section provides guidance for rolling back to a previous release of " "OpenStack. Although only tested on Ubuntu, other distributions follow a " "similar <phrase role=\"keep-together\">procedure</phrase>.<indexterm "#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2864(para)"storage volumes, and so on. Any of these new resources will be in a zombie " "state after the databases are restored from backup."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2875(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2880(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2884(para) msgid "Restore databases from backup."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2888(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2892(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2904(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2909(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2912(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2916(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2923(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2930(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2942(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2945(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml2952(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml3000(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml3007(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml3038(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml3090(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml3097(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml3106(para)

Imported Translations from Transifex

For more information about this automatic import see:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Translations/Infrastructure

Change-Id: I7d1fceaa4800d606ec27f50c4a674900ab3103d4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/90/167890/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "POT-Creation-Date: 2015-03-25 19:43+0000\n" "PO-Revision-Date: 2015-03-26 03:30+0000\n""Once a user is authenticated a token is generated for authorization and " "access to an OpenStack environment. A token can have a variable life span; " "however since the release of OpenStack Icehouse, the default value for " "expiry has been reduced to one hour. The recommended expiry value should be " "set to a lower value that allows enough time for internal services to " "complete tasks. In the event that the token expires before tasks complete, " "the cloud may become unresponsive or stop providing services. An example of " "expended time during use would be the time needed by the Compute service to " "transfer a disk image onto the hypervisor for local caching."#: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml271(para)"The following example shows a PKI token. Note that token id values are " "typically 3500 bytes. In this example, the value has been truncated."#: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml275(para) msgid "" "The token is often passed within the structure of a larger context of an " "Identity service response. These responses also provide a catalog of the " "various OpenStack services. Each service is listed with its name, access " "endpoints for internal, admin, and public access." msgstr "" #: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml280(para)#: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml287(title)#: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml288(para)#: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml297(para)#: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml303(para)
deleted_lines: "POT-Creation-Date: 2015-03-24 20:10+0000\n" "PO-Revision-Date: 2015-03-24 20:10+0000\n""Once a user is authenticated, a token is generated and used internally in " "OpenStack for authorization and access. The default token <emphasis " "role=\"bold\">lifespan</emphasis> is <emphasis role=\"bold\">one " "hour</emphasis>. Note that the default changed from 24 hours to 1 hour with " "the OpenStack Icehouse release. It is recommended that this value be set " "lower but caution needs to be taken as some internal services will need " "sufficient time to complete their work. The cloud may not provide services " "if tokens expire too early. An example of this would be the time needed by " "the Compute service to transfer a disk image onto the hypervisor for local " "caching."#: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml272(para)"The following example shows a PKI token. Note that, in practice, the token " "id value is about 3500 bytes. We shorten it in this example." msgstr "以下は PKI トークンの例です。実際は token id の値が約3500バイトであることに注意してください。この例では短くしています。" #: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml276(para) msgid "" "Note that the token is often passed within the structure of a larger context" " of an Identity service response. These responses also provide a catalog of " "the various OpenStack services. Each service is listed with its name, access" " endpoints for internal, admin, and public access."#: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml281(para)#: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml288(title)#: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml289(para)#: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml298(para)#: ./security-guide/ch_identity.xml304(para)

commit_message:
Ceilometer retrieve all images by 'all-tenants'

There is a TODO item in ceilometer/image/glance.py that Ceilometer need
querying images from glance twice to get all tenants' images, that because
the glance didn't provide all-tenants retrieving logical previously.
Now, glance has provided the functionality, So we need to reduce the
out-dated implementation in Ceilometer.

Change-Id: I9eba3bf56da445608db65c8205eead3bf0d568c0
Closes-Bug: #1436209

deleted_lines: u'id': u'1d21a8d0-25f4-4e0a-b4ec-85f40237676b', def _do_test_iter_images(self, page_size=0): filters={'is_public': False}, **kwargs) self.assertEqual(len(set(image.id for image in images)), len(images)) self._do_test_iter_images(100) self._do_test_iter_images() self._do_test_iter_images(-1) self.assertEqual(3, len(samples)) self.assertEqual(3, len(samples))

subject: Convert vsctl call to ovsdb
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-13 22:47:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/4834d4a62274a5b1fdd51c0a6cf1b4ad1c692e1b', 'message': "Convert vsctl call to ovsdb WIP - DO NOT MERGE

This is very much a work in progress. And I'm in the middle of a
refactor, but I thought I'd throw this up here a) for backup
purposes and b) so people can comment on the general structure.

To play with it, make sure to have devstack
  chmod a+rwx /var/run/openvswitch/db.sock.
when restarting openvswitch. Yes, permissions are a thing we'll have
to work out.

Though tempest tests ran, when running devstack vif_plugging is still
failing. Lots of work to do on safety, exceptions, testing, etc.

Change-Id: I9788f45f918664c8180adcb5a043f5b6cb55e0e3
Implements: blueprint vsctl-to-ovsdb
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-09-23 02:29:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/f1223f6c951f87911757e381731d1df38c251f9e', 'message': "Convert vsctl call to ovsdb WIP - DO NOT MERGE

This is very much a work in progress, but I'm posting a) for backup
purposes and b) so people can comment on the general structure.

This adds a neutron/agent/linux/ovs_lib module which dynamically
proxies calls to either the old ovs_lib or the new one depending on
the config variable DEFAULT/ovs_lib_version.

To play with it, make sure to have devstack
  chmod a+rwx /var/run/openvswitch/db.sock.
when restarting openvswitch. Yes, permissions are a thing we'll have
to work out. Also, in local.conf make sure that neutron.conf has
something like:

[[post-config|/$NEUTRON_CONF]]
[DEFAULT]
ovs_lib_version = 2

TODO:
  OVS's python IDL library caches data which currently needs to be
  refreshed by calling _idl.run() when querying data to make sure
  changes that have happned outside of the current process are
  reflected. I have hacked in a call to refresh when calling
  get_vif_port_set() to make plug/unplug work, but a more general
  solution needs to be implemented. It gets a little tricky because
  you can't call _idl.run() in the middle of an ongoing transaction.

  I'm currently writing functional tests that will compare ovs_lib1
  and ovs_lib2 to ensure that backward compatible behavior is
  maintained.

Change-Id: I9788f45f918664c8180adcb5a043f5b6cb55e0e3
Implements: blueprint vsctl-to-ovsdb
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-09-23 04:05:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/152e844d410a5cc53b858b1eff38de1f813d3bf6', 'message': "Convert vsctl call to ovsdb WIP - DO NOT MERGE

This is very much a work in progress, but I'm posting a) for backup
purposes and b) so people can comment on the general structure.

This adds a neutron/agent/linux/ovs_lib module which dynamically
proxies calls to either the old ovs_lib or the new one depending on
the config variable DEFAULT/ovs_lib_version.

To play with it, make sure to have devstack
  chmod a+rwx /var/run/openvswitch/db.sock.
when restarting openvswitch. Yes, permissions are a thing we'll have
to work out. Also, in local.conf make sure that neutron.conf has
something like:

[[post-config|/$NEUTRON_CONF]]
[DEFAULT]
ovs_lib_version = 2

TODO:
  OVS's python IDL library caches data which currently needs to be
  refreshed by calling _idl.run() when querying data to make sure
  changes that have happned outside of the current process are
  reflected. I have hacked in a call to refresh when calling
  get_vif_port_set() to make plug/unplug work, but a more general
  solution needs to be implemented. It gets a little tricky because
  you can't call _idl.run() in the middle of an ongoing transaction.

  I'm currently writing functional tests that will compare ovs_lib1
  and ovs_lib2 to ensure that backward compatible behavior is
  maintained.

Change-Id: I9788f45f918664c8180adcb5a043f5b6cb55e0e3
Implements: blueprint vsctl-to-ovsdb

ovs_lib_version = 2

TODO:
  OVS's python IDL library caches data which currently needs to be
  refreshed by calling _idl.run() when querying data to make sure
  changes that have happned outside of the current process are
  reflected. I have hacked in a call to refresh when calling
  get_vif_port_set() to make plug/unplug work, but a more general
  solution needs to be implemented. It gets a little tricky because
  you can't call _idl.run() in the middle of an ongoing transaction.

  I'm currently writing functional tests that will compare ovs_lib1
  and ovs_lib2 to ensure that backward compatible behavior is
  maintained.

Change-Id: I9788f45f918664c8180adcb5a043f5b6cb55e0e3
Implements: blueprint vsctl-to-ovsdb

commit_message:
Convert vsctl call to ovsdb

This is very much a work in progress, but I'm posting a) for backup
purposes and b) so people can comment on the general structure.

This adds a neutron/agent/linux/ovs_lib module which dynamically
proxies calls to either the old ovs_lib or the new one depending on
the config variable DEFAULT/ovs_lib_version.

To play with it, make sure to have devstack
  chmod a+rwx /var/run/openvswitch/db.sock.
when restarting openvswitch. Yes, permissions are a thing we'll have
to work out. Also, in local.conf make sure that neutron.conf has
something like:

[[post-config|/$NEUTRON_CONF]]
[DEFAULT]
ovs_lib_version = 2

TODO:
  OVS's python IDL library caches data which currently needs to be
  refreshed by calling _idl.run() when querying data to make sure
  changes that have happened outside of the current process are
  reflected. I have hacked in a call to refresh when calling
  get_vif_port_set() to make plug/unplug work, but a more general
  solution needs to be implemented. It gets a little tricky because
  you can't call _idl.run() in the middle of an ongoing transaction.

Change-Id: I9788f45f918664c8180adcb5a043f5b6cb55e0e3
Implements: blueprint vsctl-to-ovsdb

commit_message:
Remove the cluster extension

The cluster extension was made obsolete by the new data sync
process defined in kilo/data_sync.

Change-Id: I095d54a51dc66bbd9f947802202f4c02e7bed64d
Signed-off-by: Joe Mills <joe@midokura.com>

deleted_lines: import collectionsfrom neutron.common import exceptions as n_exc session.add(db) class MidonetClusterException(n_exc.NeutronException): message = _("Midonet Cluster Error: %(msg)s") class MidoClusterMixin(object): def _flush(self, context): try: context.session.execute('LOCK TABLES midonet_tasks WRITE') with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): context.session.execute('TRUNCATE TABLE midonet_tasks') create_task(context, FLUSH, task_id=1) finally: context.session.execute('UNLOCK TABLES') def _import(self, context): try: # lock the entire database so we can take a snapshot of the # data we need. context.session.execute('FLUSH TABLES WITH READ LOCK') database = collections.OrderedDict({ NETWORK: self.get_networks(context), SUBNET: self.get_subnets(context), PORT: self.get_ports(context), ROUTER: self.get_routers(context), FLOATING_IP: self.get_floatingips(context), SECURITY_GROUP: self.get_security_groups(context), SECURITY_GROUP_RULE: self.get_security_group_rules(context), POOL: self.get_pools(context), VIP: self.get_vips(context), HEALTH_MONITOR: self.get_health_monitors(context), MEMBER: self.get_members(context)}) # record how much items we have processed so far. We compare # this to another count after we lock midonet_tasks to make # sure nothing snuck in between the locks. task_count = context.session.query(Task).count() finally: context.session.execute('UNLOCK TABLES') try: context.session.execute('LOCK TABLES midonet_tasks WRITE') with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): if task_count != context.session.query(Task).count(): error_msg = ("The database has been updated while the " "rebuild operation is in progress") raise MidonetClusterException(msg=error_msg) for key in database: for item in database[key]: create_task(context, CREATE, data_type=key, resource_id=item['id'], data=item) finally: context.session.execute('UNLOCK TABLES') def create_cluster(self, context, cluster): LOG.info(_LI('MidoClusterMixin.create_cluster called: cluster=%r'), cluster) op = cluster['cluster']['op'] if op == OP_FLUSH: self._flush(context) elif op == OP_IMPORT: self._import(context) # Neutron assumes that any create_* call returns a dictionary. Even # though we do nothing with 'cluster', we still return it back to # neutron to satisfy this assumption. LOG.info(_LI("MidoClusterMixin.create_cluster exiting: cluster=%r"), cluster) return cluster

commit_message:
Set the flags a little earlier in cleanup

init_conf() sets some flags like IS_HEAT or IS_GLANCE.
These flags should be set before they are used in
get_tenant_cleanup_services() or get_global_cleanup_services().
Otherwise, the services like StackService or ImageService would not
be added into tenant_services or global_services in
get_tenant_cleanup_services() or get_global_cleanup_services(),
causing the resources for these related services un-cleaned
by cleanup.py module.

Change-Id: I46bae722631283c43b87a17ef4c69aaec0c1fda9
Closes-Bug: #1395472

commit_message:
Moves ovs_lib to agent/common

This patch moves ovs_lib from agent/linux to agent/common
since it will be used by ovs_neutron_agent on both Linux
and Windows platforms. To provide compatibility with out of
tree code, a placeholder has been left in agent/linux.

Unit tests are updated accordingly.

Partially implements blueprint: hyper-v-ovs-agent

Change-Id: I009f7f5e3b014633541ed5a45628aa1b2287e22b

added_lines: @patch('magnum.openstack.common.utils.trycmd') def test_rc_delete(self, mock_trycmd): expected_api_address = 'master-address' expected_rc_name = 'test-rc' expected_command = [ 'kubectl', 'delete', 'rc', expected_rc_name, '-s', expected_api_address ] mock_trycmd.return_value = ("", "") result = self.kube_client.rc_delete(expected_api_address, expected_rc_name) self.assertTrue(result) mock_trycmd.assert_called_once_with(*expected_command) @patch('magnum.openstack.common.utils.trycmd') def test_rc_delete_failure_exception(self, mock_trycmd): expected_api_address = 'master-address' expected_rc_name = 'test-rc' expected_command = [ 'kubectl', 'delete', 'rc', expected_rc_name, '-s', expected_api_address ] mock_trycmd.side_effect = Exception() result = self.kube_client.rc_delete(expected_api_address, expected_rc_name) self.assertFalse(result) mock_trycmd.assert_called_once_with(*expected_command) @patch('magnum.openstack.common.utils.trycmd') def test_rc_delete_not_found(self, mock_trycmd): expected_api_address = 'master-address' expected_rc_name = 'test-rc' expected_command = [ 'kubectl', 'delete', 'rc', expected_rc_name, '-s', expected_api_address ] mock_trycmd.return_value = ("", 'rc "test-rc" not found') self.assertRaises(exception.ReplicationControllerNotFound, self.kube_client.rc_delete, expected_api_address, expected_rc_name) mock_trycmd.assert_called_once_with(*expected_command)

commit_message:
Add some useful notes in  devref/db_layer.rst

Added information about difference between default and server_default
parameters for columns.

This was suggested in comments to I466202ac8c378f1e19e42ec2880d0c8fbc35fd28.

Related-bug: #1295539

Change-Id: I605ab8a4f3af80497fb8ad21d43fa13d8d533325
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/33/167233/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This section contains some common information that will be useful for developers that need to do some db changes. Difference between 'default' and 'server_default' parameters for columns ------------------------------------------------------------------------ For columns it is possible to set 'default' or 'server_default'. What is the difference between them and why should they be used? The explanation is quite simple: * ``default`` - the default value that would be reached via code; * ``server_default`` - the default value that we want to set in database for the column. Summarizing, 'default' is useless in migrations and only 'server_default' should be used. For synchronization models with migrations server_default should also be added in model too. If default value in database is not needed, 'server_default' should not be used.

commit_message:
Add a set of tests to the in memory fake filesystem

To ensure this continues to work as expected add some
basic functional tests that ensure the existing operations
work (and continue to work).

Change-Id: I2903bf29a77936d850d667d1fbff179a14a57adb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/55/167055/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from taskflow import exceptions as exc class MemoryFilesystemTest(test.TestCase): @staticmethod def _get_item_path(fs, path): # TODO(harlowja): is there a better way to do this?? return fs[path] @staticmethod def _del_item_path(fs, path): # TODO(harlowja): is there a better way to do this?? del fs[path] def test_set_get_ls(self): fs = impl_memory.FakeFilesystem() fs['/d'] = 'd' fs['/c'] = 'c' fs['/d/b'] = 'db' self.assertEqual(2, len(fs.ls('/'))) self.assertEqual(1, len(fs.ls('/d'))) self.assertEqual('d', fs['/d']) self.assertEqual('c', fs['/c']) self.assertEqual('db', fs['/d/b']) def test_ensure_path(self): fs = impl_memory.FakeFilesystem() pieces = ['a', 'b', 'c'] path = "/" + "/".join(pieces) fs.ensure_path(path) path = fs.root_path for i, p in enumerate(pieces): if i == 0: path += p else: path += "/" + p self.assertIsNone(fs[path]) def test_not_found(self): fs = impl_memory.FakeFilesystem() self.assertRaises(exc.NotFound, self._get_item_path, fs, '/c') def test_del_root_not_allowed(self): fs = impl_memory.FakeFilesystem() self.assertRaises(ValueError, self._del_item_path, fs, '/') def test_link_loop_raises(self): fs = impl_memory.FakeFilesystem() fs['/b'] = 'c' fs.symlink('/b', '/b') self.assertRaises(ValueError, self._get_item_path, fs, '/b') def test_ensure_linked_delete(self): fs = impl_memory.FakeFilesystem() fs['/b'] = 'd' fs.symlink('/b', '/c') self.assertEqual('d', fs['/b']) self.assertEqual('d', fs['/c']) del fs['/b'] self.assertRaises(exc.NotFound, self._get_item_path, fs, '/c') self.assertRaises(exc.NotFound, self._get_item_path, fs, '/b')

commit_message:
Add more comments to fake in-memory filesystem

Ensure users of this code/objects are aware that only
posixpath style paths will work (and not the variant
that is used in os.path which can change depending
on operating system) as well as adding docstrings on
other methods so that they show up in the generated
docs.

Change-Id: I5a21cb75b2452b9c9d65860b63658a9d0980025f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/31/167831/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """An in-memory filesystem-like structure. This filesystem uses posix style paths **only** so users must be careful to use the ``posixpath`` module instead of the ``os.path`` one which will vary depending on the operating system which the active python is running in (the decision to use ``posixpath`` was to avoid the path variations which are not relevant in an implementation of a in-memory fake filesystem). """

commit_message:
remove references to database downgrades

There are already essentially no references to downgrades, but this
commit clarifies that the user must make a backup as there is no other
alternative.

Change-Id: I5354218ac57b37f65d25e369fb31f40b92f94a5c
Closes-Bug: #1435529

added_lines: <para>If possible, it is highly recommended that you dump your production database tables and test the upgrade in your development environment using this data. As stated above, several mysql bugs have been uncovered during database migrations that will only be hit on large real datasets. You do not want to find this out in the middle of a production outage.</para> <para>Make a full database backup of your production data. As of Kilo, database downgrades are not supported, and the only method available to get back to a prior database version will be restore from backup.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Upgrades involve complex operations and can fail. Before attempting any upgrade, you should make a full database backup of your production data. As of Kilo, database downgrades are not supported, and the only method available to get back to a prior database version will be restore from backup.</para> <para>This section provides guidance for rolling back to a previous release of OpenStack. Although only tested on Ubuntu, other <para>Restore databases from backup.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>Upgrades involve complex operations and can fail. This section provides guidance for rolling back to a previous release of OpenStack. Although only tested on Ubuntu, other <para>Roll back databases.</para>

commit_message:
Modify message queue content for Kilo

Modify message queue content for Kilo as follows:

1) Use upstream repository to obtain recent version of RabbitMQ.

   * Only impacts Ubuntu.

2) Create "openstack" account instead of using the "guest"
   account.

3) Replace "message broker" with "message queue" to improve
   wording.

   * Additional patches should implement this change.

Change-Id: Ieb126c768e32cb5b479468b31cd7e4f63537ff2e
Implements: blueprint installguide-kilo
Closes-Bug: #1423155
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/17/167717/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: xml:id="basics-message-queue"> <title>Message queue</title> <para>OpenStack uses a <glossterm>message queue</glossterm> to coordinate operations and status information among services. The message queue message queue services including <application>RabbitMQ</application>, message queue service. This guide implements the RabbitMQ message queue service because most distributions support it. If you prefer to implement a different message queue service, consult the documentation associated <title>To install the message queue service</title> <step os="ubuntu"> <para>Add the upstream repository key:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>curl -O https://www.rabbitmq.com/rabbitmq-signing-key-public.asc</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>apt-key add rabbitmq-signing-key-public.asc</userinput></screen> </step> <step os="ubuntu"> <para>Add the upstream repository:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>echo "deb http://www.rabbitmq.com/debian/ testing main" \ > /etc/apt/sources.list.d/rabbitmq.list</userinput></screen> </step> <step os="ubuntu"> <para>Update the package database:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>apt-get update</userinput></screen> </step> <para>Install the package:</para> <title>To configure the message queue service</title> <para>Start the message queue service and configure it to start when the <para>Add the <literal>openstack</literal> user:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>rabbitmqctl add_user openstack <replaceable>RABBIT_PASS</replaceable></userinput> <computeroutput>Creating user "openstack" ...</computeroutput></screen> <para>Permit configuration, write, and read access for the <literal>openstack</literal> user:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>rabbitmqctl set_permissions openstack ".*" ".*" ".*"</userinput> <computeroutput>Setting permissions for user "openstack" in vhost "/" ...</computeroutput></screen>
deleted_lines: xml:id="basics-messaging-server"> <title>Messaging server</title> <para>OpenStack uses a <glossterm>message broker</glossterm> to coordinate operations and status information among services. The message broker message brokers including <application>RabbitMQ</application>, message broker. This guide covers the RabbitMQ message broker which is supported by each distribution. If you prefer to implement a different message broker, consult the documentation associated <title>To install the <application>RabbitMQ</application> message broker service</title> <title>To configure the message broker service</title> <para>Start the message broker service and configure it to start when the <para>The message broker creates a default account that uses <literal>guest</literal> for the username and password. To simplify installation of your test environment, we recommend that you use this account, but change the password for it.</para> <para>Run the following command:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>rabbitmqctl change_password guest <replaceable>RABBIT_PASS</replaceable></userinput> <computeroutput>Changing password for user "guest" ... ...done.</computeroutput></screen> <para>You must configure the <literal>rabbit_password</literal> key in the configuration file for each OpenStack service that uses the message broker.</para> <note> <para>For production environments, you should create a unique account with a suitable password. For more information on securing the message broker, see the <link xlink:href="https://www.rabbitmq.com/man/rabbitmqctl.1.man.html" >documentation</link>.</para> <para>If you decide to create a unique account with a suitable password for your test environment, you must configure the <literal>rabbit_userid</literal> and <literal>rabbit_password</literal> keys in the configuration file of each OpenStack service that uses the message broker.</para> </note> <para>For RabbitMQ version 3.3.0 or newer, you must enable remote access for the <literal>guest</literal> account.</para> <substeps> <step> <para>Check the RabbitMQ version:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>rabbitmqctl status | grep rabbit</userinput> <computeroutput>Status of node 'rabbit@controller' ... {running_applications,[{rabbit,"RabbitMQ","3.4.2"},</computeroutput></screen> </step> <step> <para>If necessary, edit the <filename>/etc/rabbitmq/rabbitmq.config</filename> file and configure <literal>loopback_users</literal> to reference an empty list:</para> <programlisting>[{rabbit, [{loopback_users, []}]}].</programlisting> <note> <para>Contents of the original file might vary depending on the source of the RabbitMQ package. In some cases, you might need to create this file.</para> </note> </step> <step> <para>Restart the message broker service:</para> <screen os="ubuntu;debian"><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>service rabbitmq-server restart</userinput></screen> <screen os="rhel;centos;fedora"><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>systemctl restart rabbitmq-server.service</userinput></screen> <para os="sles">On SLES:</para> <screen os="sles"><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>service rabbitmq-server restart</userinput></screen> <para os="opensuse">On openSUSE:</para> <screen os="opensuse"><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>systemctl restart rabbitmq-server.service</userinput></screen> </step> </substeps>

added_lines: @patch('magnum.openstack.common.utils.trycmd') def test_service_delete(self, mock_trycmd): expected_api_address = 'master-address' expected_service_name = 'test-service' expected_command = [ 'kubectl', 'delete', 'service', expected_service_name, '-s', expected_api_address ] mock_trycmd.return_value = ("", "") result = self.kube_client.service_delete(expected_api_address, expected_service_name) self.assertTrue(result) mock_trycmd.assert_called_once_with(*expected_command) @patch('magnum.openstack.common.utils.trycmd') def test_service_delete_failure_exception(self, mock_trycmd): expected_api_address = 'master-address' expected_service_name = 'test-service' expected_command = [ 'kubectl', 'delete', 'service', expected_service_name, '-s', expected_api_address ] mock_trycmd.side_effect = Exception() result = self.kube_client.service_delete(expected_api_address, expected_service_name) self.assertFalse(result) mock_trycmd.assert_called_once_with(*expected_command) @patch('magnum.openstack.common.utils.trycmd') def test_service_delete_not_found(self, mock_trycmd): expected_api_address = 'master-address' expected_service_name = 'test-service' expected_command = [ 'kubectl', 'delete', 'service', expected_service_name, '-s', expected_api_address ] mock_trycmd.return_value = ("", 'service "test-service" not found') self.assertRaises(exception.ServiceNotFound, self.kube_client.service_delete, expected_api_address, expected_service_name) mock_trycmd.assert_called_once_with(*expected_command)

commit_message:
Remove HaRouter.verify_ha

All of the methods that use it are now part of the HaRouter
class. The check has outlived its usefulness and may die
a peaceful yet horrifying death. At its point of death,
verify_ha is akin to a guy walking down the street and yelling:
'Am I me? Am I me?' - Yes, you're you, shut up. An HA router
is an HA router, there's no point in the class checking if
it's indeed an HA router.

Partially-Implements: bp/restructure-l3-agent
Change-Id: Ia440c9f7ae733fed9a38df10b3262a88a85b07ad

commit_message:
Rename/move/remove HaRouter methods

All of the methods that use verify_ha are now part of the HaRouter
class. The check has outlived its usefulness and may die
a peaceful yet horrifying death. At its point of death,
verify_ha is akin to a guy walking down the street and yelling:
'Am I me? Am I me?' - Yes, you're you, shut up. An HA router
is an HA router, there's no point in the class checking if
it's indeed an HA router.

* keepalived_manager._get_full_config_file_path was being used
  outside of the keepalived_manager, removed the leading underscore
* _ha_get_existing_cidrs doesn't need an 'ha' prefix, it's already
  a part of the HA router class. This patch renames the method to
  a more descriptive name
* HARouter._get_ipv6_lladdr had nothing to do with HA routers, nor
  did it use the HARouter state. Moved it to ip_lib

Partially-Implements: bp/restructure-l3-agent
Change-Id: I6a7df0b08ca3fc8c2c1b310aa8dd897111f52974

commit_message:
DO NOT MERGE: Scheduler Raises NoValidHostNotComplete when it doesn't have complete view

This is a proof-of-concept code demo of how scheduler host manager
can be altered to provide more information to mitigate some corner
scheduler we have seen, like bug #1409012.

Please DO NOT MERGE.

Change-Id: Ib7bbe7b1f8ed84f7f6043fcaa88b4ef1bc4479f3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/50/162050/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # A set of hosts that don't have up-to-date stats outofdate_hosts = set() if capabilities is None or not utils.stats_is_uptodate(capabilities): LOG.warn(_LW("Scheduler does not have complete " "view of all active backends: (host %s) stats is" "out-of-date." % host)) outofdate_hosts.add(host) continue return outofdate_hosts ofd_hosts = self._update_host_state_map(context) return ofd_hosts, all_pools.itervalues()

commit_message:
Generic Volume Migration Support - Proof-of-Concept (DO NO MERGE)

This is a POC change, which is served as code example for better
abstraction of generic volume migration support.

PLEASE DO NOT MERGE this one, and focus on this one instead:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/135002/5

Change-Id: Ia5a01c2413993a5c98bddde663fa43488673d809
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/94/161094/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder.volume.drivers.rbd import RBDDriver from cinder.volume.drivers.rbd import RBDImageIOWrapper, RBDImageMetadata from cinder.volume.drivers.rbd import RBDVolumeProxy elif protocol == 'rbd': return RBDConnector(root_helper=root_helper, driver=driver, execute=execute, device_scan_attempts=device_scan_attempts, *args, **kwargs) def check_valid_device(self, device, run_as_root=True): """Validate if connected volume is accessable. A volume is connected to host either via a host device (like most storage protocols) or a file handler. This function verifies if the connected volume can be read. For those drivers that are able to do both (host device & file handler), this function only checks host device. """ path = device.get('path', None) if path is not None: # volume is connected to host as a host device cmd = ('dd', 'if=%(path)s' % {"path": path}, 'of=/dev/null', 'count=1') out, info = None, None try: out, info = self._execute(*cmd, run_as_root=run_as_root, root_helper=self._root_helper) except putils.ProcessExecutionError as e: LOG.error(_LE("Failed to access the device on the path " "%(path)s: %(error)s %(info)s.") % {"path": path, "error": e.stderr, "info": info}) return False # If the info is none, the path does not exist. if info is None: return False return True else: handler = device.get('handle', None) if handler is not None: try: info = handler.read(4096) except Exception as e: LOG.error(_LE("Failed to access the device" " handler: %(error)s") % {"error": str(e)}) return False return True class RBDConnector(InitiatorConnector): """Connector class to attach/detach RBD volumes.""" def __init__(self, root_helper, driver=None, execute=putils.execute, use_multipath=False, device_scan_attempts=DEVICE_SCAN_ATTEMPTS_DEFAULT, *args, **kwargs): super(RBDConnector, self).__init__(root_helper, driver=driver, execute=execute, device_scan_attempts= device_scan_attempts, *args, **kwargs) if driver: self.driver = driver else: # Initialize a RBD driver instance conn = kwargs.get('conn', None) if not conn: raise exception.InvalidParameterValue('RBD connection need conn') rbd_pool = conn['data']['name'].split("/")[0] rbd_user = conn['data']['auth_username'] conf = {'mon hosts': conn['data']['hosts'] + ":" + conn['data']['ports']} self.driver = RBDDriver(*args, rbd_user=rbd_user, rbd_pool=rbd_pool, conf=conf, **kwargs) def set_execute(self, execute): super(RBDConnector, self).set_execute(execute) def connect_volume(self, connection_properties): """Connect a volume. connection_properties for RBD must include: 'name' - full path for RBD image, which includes RBD pool and RBD image name 'auth_username' - rbd user to connect to RBD pool 'hosts', 'ports' - Ceph mon IP address(es) and port(s) """ pool, volume_name = connection_properties['name'].split("/") rbd_user = connection_properties['auth_username'] rbd_image = RBDVolumeProxy(self.driver, volume_name, pool) mon_addrs = connection_properties['hosts'] \ + ":" + connection_properties['ports'] conf = {'mon hosts': mon_addrs} rbd_meta = RBDImageMetadata(rbd_image, pool, rbd_user, None, conf_dict=conf) rbd_handle = RBDImageIOWrapper(rbd_meta) return {'handle': rbd_handle, 'private': rbd_image} def disconnect_volume(self, connection_properties, device_info): """Detach the RBD volume from host. connection_properties for RBD must include: 'name' - full path for RBD image, which includes RBD pool and RBD image name 'auth_username' - rbd user to connect to RBD pool 'hosts', 'ports' - Ceph mon IP address(es) and port(s) """ rbd_image = connection_properties['device']['private'] rbd_image.close() #XXX FIXME disconnect_from_rados should be called # or RBDVolumeProxy.close has already done that?
deleted_lines: def check_valid_device(self, path, run_as_root=True): cmd = ('dd', 'if=%(path)s' % {"path": path}, 'of=/dev/null', 'count=1') out, info = None, None try: out, info = self._execute(*cmd, run_as_root=run_as_root, root_helper=self._root_helper) except putils.ProcessExecutionError as e: LOG.error(_LE("Failed to access the device on the path " "%(path)s: %(error)s %(info)s.") % {"path": path, "error": e.stderr, "info": info}) return False # If the info is none, the path does not exist. if info is None: return False return True

commit_message:
Cisco Nexus1000V ML2 Mechanism Driver

Introduces the Cisco Nexus1000V Mechanism driver for ML2 plugin.
All the vendor specific code resides in stackforge repo networking-cisco.

Closes-Bug: #1425632
Partial-Implements: blueprint core-vendor-decomposition

Change-Id: I66bf83f45bf1e0269d0876196f6aa032b0fa859f
Co-Authored-By: Steven Hillman <sthillma@cisco.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/43/157243/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 OpenStack Foundation # All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import sqlalchemy as sa from neutron.db import model_base from neutron.db import models_v2 from neutron.plugins.common import constants class PolicyProfile(model_base.BASEV2): """ Nexus1000V Policy Profiles Both 'profile_id' and 'name' are populated from Nexus1000V switch. """ __tablename__ = 'cisco_ml2_n1kv_policy_profiles' id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), nullable=False, primary_key=True) name = sa.Column(sa.String(255), nullable=False) vsm_ip = sa.Column(sa.String(16), nullable=False, primary_key=True) class NetworkProfile(model_base.BASEV2, models_v2.HasId): """Nexus1000V Network Profiles created on the VSM.""" __tablename__ = 'cisco_ml2_n1kv_network_profiles' name = sa.Column(sa.String(255), nullable=False) segment_type = sa.Column(sa.Enum(constants.TYPE_VLAN, constants.TYPE_VXLAN, name='segment_type'), nullable=False) sub_type = sa.Column(sa.String(255)) segment_range = sa.Column(sa.String(255)) multicast_ip_index = sa.Column(sa.Integer, default=0) multicast_ip_range = sa.Column(sa.String(255)) physical_network = sa.Column(sa.String(255)) class N1kvPortBinding(model_base.BASEV2): """Represents binding of ports to policy profile.""" __tablename__ = 'cisco_ml2_n1kv_port_bindings' port_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey('ports.id', ondelete="CASCADE"), primary_key=True) profile_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey('cisco_ml2_n1kv_policy_profiles.id'), nullable=False) class N1kvNetworkBinding(model_base.BASEV2): """Represents binding of virtual network to network profiles.""" __tablename__ = 'cisco_ml2_n1kv_network_bindings' network_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey('networks.id', ondelete="CASCADE"), primary_key=True) network_type = sa.Column(sa.String(32), nullable=False) segmentation_id = sa.Column(sa.Integer) profile_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey('cisco_ml2_n1kv_network_profiles.id'), nullable=False) class N1kvVlanAllocation(model_base.BASEV2): """Represents allocation state of vlan_id on physical network.""" __tablename__ = 'cisco_ml2_n1kv_vlan_allocations' physical_network = sa.Column(sa.String(64), nullable=False, primary_key=True) vlan_id = sa.Column(sa.Integer, nullable=False, primary_key=True, autoincrement=False) allocated = sa.Column(sa.Boolean, nullable=False, default=False) network_profile_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey( 'cisco_ml2_n1kv_network_profiles.id', ondelete="CASCADE"), nullable=False) class N1kvVxlanAllocation(model_base.BASEV2): """Represents allocation state of vxlan_id.""" __tablename__ = 'cisco_ml2_n1kv_vxlan_allocations' vxlan_id = sa.Column(sa.Integer, nullable=False, primary_key=True, autoincrement=False) allocated = sa.Column(sa.Boolean, nullable=False, default=False) network_profile_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey( 'cisco_ml2_n1kv_network_profiles.id', ondelete="CASCADE"), nullable=False) class ProfileBinding(model_base.BASEV2): """ Represents a binding of Network Profile or Policy Profile to tenant_id """ __tablename__ = 'cisco_ml2_n1kv_profile_bindings' profile_type = sa.Column(sa.Enum('network', 'policy', name='profile_type')) tenant_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), primary_key=True, default='tenant_id_not_set', server_default='tenant_id_not_set') profile_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), primary_key=True)

commit_message:
Remove unused code

Magnum get/show pod/rc/service from db directly, not call
kubectl, and besides those code not tested and have no function
needs now. We can add them according to needs later.
Closes-Bug: #1436628

Change-Id: Ibd75eae3a6b6408a035f7889d6dbf527a70b3505
